Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Pain in Self-Reduction vs. Physician-Guided Reduction of Anterior Shoulder Dislocations

Trial_Design.evidence: single-center, observer-blinded trial included patients aged 18-60 with acute anterior shoulder dislocations

Participants.evidence: patients aged 18-60 with acute anterior shoulder dislocations. Conducted at a tertiary referral center's emergency department

Intervention.evidence: self-reduction using the Boss-Holzach-Matter (BHM) technique versus physician-guided reduction using the Spaso technique

Objective.evidence: aimed to compare the pain experienced during self-reduction using the Boss-Holzach-Matter (BHM) technique versus physician-guided reduction using the Spaso technique

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pain during reduction, measured on a 0-10 visual analogue scale (VAS) immediately post-reduction

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomly allocated to either the Sp group (n=30) or the BHM group (n=30) using block randomization with sealed opaque envelopes

Number_Randomised.evidence: From May 2015 to February 2017, 60 patients were randomized

Result_Outcome.evidence: The BHM group reported significantly less pain (mean VAS 3.57, SD 2.1) compared to the Sp group (mean VAS 5.26, SD 2.9; p=0.047)

Harms.evidence: No complications were reported in either group

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT02527603)
